perturbation.original_text: 16.01 Investor at any time may provide written notice to Company of a material breach of this IP Agreement. If Company fails to cure the identified breach within thirty (30) days after the date of the notice, Investor may terminate this IP Agreement by written notice to Company.
perturbation.changed_text: 16.01 Investor at any time may provide written notice to Company of a material breach of this IP Agreement. If Company fails to cure the identified breach within ten (10) days after the date of the notice, Investor may terminate this IP Agreement by written notice to Company.
perturbation.explanation: Reducing the cure period for a material breach to 10 days may be considered unreasonable in some jurisdictions and could conflict with principles of good faith and fair dealing, particularly in complex commercial agreements where a longer period may be necessary to remedy the breach. This is an issue because contract laws generally expect reasonable time for remediation depending on the complexity of the breach. Under California law, for example, a breach of contract claim might be challenged if the breaching party wasn't given a commercially reasonable cure period.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Breach of Contract Laws, Principles of Good Faith and Fair Dealing, California Contract Law

perturbation.changed_text:
18.01 Negotiations. The Parties shall first attempt in good faith to resolve any Dispute by negotiation and consultation between
themselves, including without limitation not fewer than two (2) negotiation sessions which shall occur within two (2) Business Days of the Dispute
Notice.
perturbation.explanation: Reducing the negotiation period to two business days may not provide sufficient time for complex disputes to be resolved, potentially conflicting with the implied covenant of good faith and fair dealing required by New York law (specified in Article 13.00). New York courts may view this as an unreasonably short time frame, especially considering the nature of intellectual property disputes which are frequently complicated and time-consuming.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Implied Covenant of Good Faith and Fair Dealing (New York Law), Contract Interpretation Principles

and will have the right to determine whether or not, and where, to file a patent application, to abandon the prosecution of any patent or patent

perturbation.changed_text:
4.00 Company will have the sole right to file, prosecute, and maintain all Patents covering the inventions that are the property of Company
and will have the right to determine whether or not, and where, to file a patent application, to abandon the prosecution of any patent or patent
application, or to discontinue the maintenance of any patent or patent application. Notwithstanding the foregoing, if Company elects to abandon
any patent application, to not pay maintenance fees or annuities to keep a patent in force, or to otherwise take or fail to take any action that will
result in a loss of patent rights, Company shall give Investor at least ten (10) days prior written notice and an opportunity to take over the
prosecution of the patent application that would be abandoned and/or pay the fees necessary to keep the patent in force and/or take any other
action necessary to avoid the loss of patent rights.
perturbation.explanation: Reducing the notice period to 10 days before abandoning a patent application may be deemed insufficient under patent law principles, as it might not provide the investor enough time to assess the patent's value, secure legal counsel, and prepare to take over prosecution. This is especially crucial in the US, as patent prosecution can be complex and require substantial preparation. A shorter timeframe could be viewed as a breach of good faith, as it hinders the investor's ability to protect its licensed rights effectively.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Patent Law Principles, Implied Covenant of Good Faith and Fair Dealing, US Patent Prosecution Rules
